refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The aq add network environment command creates a new network environment.

Network environments represent distinct administrative domains for the IPv4 Private Address Space, as defined by RFC 1918. Inside the same network environment, the use of RFC 1918 address ranges must be coherent and non-overlapping. A different network environment however may re-use the same address ranges for a different purpose.

Let's consider IP address 192.168.0.1 is in use somewhere in the organization. Assume you want to place a new server at an external hosting provider. This server has a public IP address that is connected to the internet, but it also has a direct link to some dedicated 3rd-party service. The provider of this service requires the use of the IP address 192.168.0.1 to access the service. This presents a problem, since the same IP address is now used by two different entities.

The problem can be solved by creating a new network environment for said 3rd-party service provider, and registering the service address inside this environment. Therefore the broker knows that although the IP address is the same, the two users of the address are different, and the broker can select the right network parameters for both users.

Note that when there is an overlap between the addresses defined in two network environments, then hosts in those environments may not be able to communicate with each other directly. Setting up routing, NAT etc. to make such communication possible is out of scope for the broker.

The default network environment is defined by the default_network_environment key in the site section of the broker's configuration. All commands will operate inside this environment unless explicitly directed otherwise.

listitem.para: The name of the network environment. The name must contain only alphanumeric characters, '_', '.' and '-'.

The name of the DNS environment that will be bound to this network environment. Any command that registers an address in NETENV and allows specifying an FQDN, will register that FQDN in DNSENV. If there is a real DNS server that serves the view DNSENV, then e.g. reverse address resolution will give you answers that are valid for NETENV, but not for any other network environment. If there is no real DNS server serving DNSENV, then it is still possible to populate /etc/hosts from the data stored in DNSENV.
Specify if the given network environment is bound to a single physical building. Currently this option is for informational purposes only.
Short description of the purpose of the network environment.
